title: Congressional Approval Rating
question_text:
A pollster is interested in the approval rating of a congressman in his district.
Using an address book to select households randomly within the representative’s constituency, the pollster went from door to door and asked, “Do you approve of your United States representative?”
What is a potential bias the pollster may encounter?

choices.text: The constituents may not be informed on the representative.
The sample was stratified on homeownership when it should not be.
The pollster is leaving out any constituents who are homeless or have unlisted addresses.
Some of these constituents may not be eligible to vote.

solution:
This question addresses the main types of bias. Students need to know all types of bias that may exist in polls and be able to identify these biases in the context of a problem.

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the wording is straightforward.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; the intentions of the pollster are unaffected by constituents’ depth of knowledge of their representative.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; this is NOT a stratified sample.

Choice 'D' is correct; this problem in particular clearly has undercoverage of the homeless and unlisted.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; the intentions of the pollster are unaffected by voter eligibility.
